>So said Dave Astels on 2003-07-25 --------------------
>--- In junit@yahoo=
groups.com, Peter Morgan <pmorgan@j...> wrote:
>> On Thu, 2003-07-24 at 19:=
15, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>> > For some odd reason I don't like setting =
expectations on an object
>then letting it verify itself. Sounds weird. I p=
refer to be the one to
>verify it. I don't know why.
>> 
>> I agree. I have=
 been mocking for some 5 years now (in our group we
>> originally called th=
em crash test dummies).
>
>We often use that phrase when describing them to=
 students.
>
>> I much prefer to query the mock object and assert whether t=
he 
>> 'correct' thing happened in the unit test.
>
>Hmm.. not very object =
opriented.  Why not tell the mock what to
>expect, and let it figure out if=
 it happened?

I shall do this from this day forward (for a while) and see =
how I feel about it. Likely it's just getting used to a new habit.

>Then y=
ou have a specification of the interaction in your test... not
>just the po=
stconditions.
>
>How do you test for correct call sequencing?

I use a log:=
 a List of pieces of information representing what was called. I verify thi=
s against an expected List.

More to the point, though, I try to avoid chec=
king for correct call sequencing, because that tests implementation and not=
 necessarily behavior.
